ygData.subject: response to latest advice
ygData.msgSnippet: Wow guys, this information is just immeasurably helpful.  Thanks a lot. The MSc programme in Evolutionary and Adaptive Systems does sound brilliant, from both

Wow guys, this information is just immeasurably helpful.  Thanks a lot.

The MSc programme in Evolutionary and Adaptive Systems does sound
brilliant, from both the website and from the quick email
correspondance I've had with Julian.  That being said, I am on my way
to visit it next week to get a thorough impression of the place and
its people before I make any decisions.  I'll let everyone know what I
think of it when I get back to Toronto.

Programme site:
http://www.sussex.ac.uk/Units/publications/pgrad2005/computing.html#5034

Julian's site:
http://julian.togelius.com/

I realized that I never asked Julian specifically if they focus on
TWEANN approaches to NE, but judging by the work that he, personally,
has done, it would appear so.  Regardless, I'll soon find out.

Ian, you mentioned that there should be lots of places to go for
guidance on the matter; to be honest, I haven't found any better than
the discussions that have been going on right here.  Many Universities
offer advice on how to apply for THEIR programmes, but that's all. 
The advice being offered here is pure gold to me.  phd-survey.org has
some general advice but it's REALLY general.

Examining the Universities in British Columbia (EA headquarters), I
see a lot of AI possibilities but nothing that mentions anything close
to NE.  Shame.

I'm glad to see your confidence in UCF, Ken.  If it works out the way
you want it to, then I'd be very excited by the notion of doing a PhD
there eventually.  Of course, I don't know how competitive it is
applying to UCF.

Thanks again,
Mike
